children.value: Use this guide to contribute to the theme. We'll show you how to get the development environment set up as quickly as possible so you can start contributing.

<AnchorLinks>
  <AnchorLink>Project setup</AnchorLink>
  <AnchorLink>Development</AnchorLink>
  <AnchorLink>Work in a branch</AnchorLink>
  <AnchorLink>Sass and CSS Modules</AnchorLink>
  <AnchorLink>VS Code</AnchorLink>
</AnchorLinks>
After it's finished, click on the
In your terminal, clone the repo into your directory of choice
When you clone your forked repo the
is set to your fork by default. You'll want to add a remote that points to the upstream repo.
In your terminal, verify that the remotes have been set
and yarn workspaces to develop the Carbon Gatsby theme. This allows us to have a development environment that's closely linked to the theme with minimal setup. Run
to install all of the projects dependencies.
This project has two packages: the actual theme package (
package. The example package emulates a project which uses the theme. Its only dependencies are Gatsby, React, and the adjacent theme package. The
package also serves as the theme's documentation and
; it's deployed on every merge to master.
New theme development will happen in the theme package while documentation and testing of that change will occur through changes in the example directory.
- check for errors in your javascript

You should always start a new project by pulling upstream changes into master and then creating a new branch. This workflow ensures you don't accidentally commit anything to your master branch and get stuck when trying to open a pull request.

git checkout master
git pull upstream master
git checkout -b my-branch-name
When you're ready to open a pull request, push to your origin remote.

You'll get a message in your terminal with a URL to open up a pull request in the upstream repository. Navigate to that URL and be sure to give a detailed summary of your pull request in the title and body section of the form.
For internal theme components we use
. This allows us to take advantage of the Carbon Design System resources while not worrying about className collisions. By default, each
file will be supplied with all of the Carbon Sass
: color, spacing, theme, and motion, as well as type and layout mixins, are imported automatically.
You should colocate your stylesheet with the component(s) that import it. If the component is
You don't need to prefix your classes as CSS Modules will generate unique class names for you. Import the class from the

import { treeView } from './style.css';

const TreeView = props => <div className={treeView} />;
For conditionally applying class names, use the
library. Note how we're using a
for the property being based to
. That's because the className isn't literally
it's a value generated by CSS Modules and placed in the
If you need to target a global class not processed by CSS Modules, you can do so with the
